bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 162, Number 164 (Wednesday, November 16, 2016)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. WALBERG:H.R. 6327.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, Clause 3 of the Constitution of theUnited States; the power to regulate commerce among theseveral states and Article I, Section 8, Clause 18 to makeall Laws which shall be necessary and propery for carryinginto Execution the foregoing Powers.[Page H6270]

item.name: Administrative State, Regulatory Reform, and Antitrust Subcommittee
Administrative State, Regulatory Reform, and Antitrust Subcommittee

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Regulatory Reform, Commercial And Antitrust Law.

Referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and in addition to the Committee on Small Business, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.

summary.text:
Main Street Input Opportunity Act of 2016

This bill includes the Department of Labor as a "covered agency" for purposes of regulatory flexibility analysis provisions.

bill.title: Main Street Input Opportunity Act of 2016

item.title: Main Street Input Opportunity Act of 2016
To amend title 5, United States Code, to require that the Department of Labor be a covered agency for purposes of regulatory flexibility analyses, and for other purposes.
Main Street Input Opportunity Act of 2016

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Regulatory Reform, Commercial And Antitrust Law.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
